newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's Malan says Oct trade deficit not a trend.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's Malan says Oct trade deficit not a trend.

text.p: Brazilian Finance Minister Pedro Malan said a record $1.308 billion October trade deficit was exceptional and did not represent a trend.
"We don't see any problem with the country posting a trade deficit. This does not indicate a trend," Malan told an audience of businessmen during a seminar on the future of the Americas.

"To take the October trade deficit and project it over time is like not seeing the forest for the trees," he told a member of the audience who asked whether the government was concerned about the unusually high October trade figure.

Malan said the government was not considering any modification to the exchange rate mechanism in place, which allows for a gentle devaluation of the real within a predetermined band, so as to promote exports and improve the trade balance.
"There are better ways than (changing) the exchange rate to boost exports," he said.
He said alternatives being explored would along the lines of a recent decree that eliminated a value added tax (ICMS) on certain exports.
"We have no doubt that exports will soon show an improvement," said Malan.
